As in other Asian languages such as Japanese and Korean, Tibetan has developed an honorific register that make it possible to express social relations through linguistic usage. The honorific should be understood as a sophisticated form of politeness expressed through personal pronouns, names, verbs, auxiliaries, and even adjectives and adverbs. The honorific register, called ཞེ་ས་, is used for people of superior and equal social standing, and even between friends and married couples. The ordinary register, སྐད་དཀྱུས་མ་, is used for all others, that is, those younger than oneself (although the honorific is sometimes used with certain juniors) and social inferiors.

Students of Tibetan should certainly learn both registers, but if you were to learn only one, the ordinary register would be better for two reasons: some people without much education hardly use the honorific register; and secondly, even if you use honorifics to another person you should always use ordinary terms (in the absence of humilifics) for yourself. And finally the good news: quite a number of words have only one form.

Most nouns, adjectives, and adverbs have only one type of honorific.

Noun

Ordinary

Honorific

Tea

ཇ་

གསོལ་ཇ་

Water

ཆུ་

ཆབ་

Book

དེབ་

ཕྱག་དེབ་

For verbs, however, as well as for pronouns, there are several types of honorific:

1. སྤྱིར་བཏང་ཞེ་ས་ The “general honorific” (H)

2. ཞེ་ས་མཐོ་པོ་ The “high honorific” (HH)

3. དམའ་ས་བཟུང་བའི་ཞེ་ས་ The “humilific” (h)

4. ཕྱོགས་གཉིས་ཀྱི་ཞེ་ས་ The “double honorific” (hH)

The general and high honorifics correspond to forms of politeness that indicate a respectful attitude toward the subject of an action. The high honorific conveys an even more polite and reverential attitude than the general honorific, and is used especially in the case of high lamas and State dignitaries. The humilific[1] is systematically used for the first person as the subject, but more generally to indicate a respectful attitude on the part of the speaker toward the person to whom that action is directed (which, from a syntactic perspective, may comprise various complements: object, indirect object, etc.). It should be emphasized that the honorific is never used with reference to oneself, and for the first person the humilific is consequently needed.

Finally, the double honorific denotes that both the subject of the action and the person to whom it is directed are considered by the speaker to merit equal respect. Note that there are only a few high and double honorifics, and they are not often used.

Here is an illustration of the different levels:

Perfect mastery of honorifics is not easy,[2] but you need not worry too much about this because Tibetans themselves often make mistakes! A common expression, “lame honorifics” (ཞེ་ས་རྐང་ཆག་), is used to signify a sentence in which the speaker puts some elements in the honorific but mistakenly leaves others on the ordinary level. The misuse of honorifics is a common source of amusement for Tibetans.                                                                                                   

The basis for a mastery of the honorific language is a sound knowledge of the pronouns and a few of the main nouns, verbs (especially the main verbs of movement, speech and action), and auxiliaries. The ཞེ་ས་ vocabulary will gradually increase with usage.

The honorific language is especially used in Standard Tibetan and the dialects of Central Tibet and Tsang, as well as certain outlying regions such as Mustang, in Nepal. It is also very important in Tibetan literature, where it may even play a grammatical role since it can substitute for the subject and other markers of person by establishing the relationship between characters, and hence identify them. Contrary to a widespread belief, the honorific is not altogether absent in the dialects of Kham and Amdo, even though it is much less frequently used than in Central Tibet.

Most honorifics are derivatives of ordinary terms, and relatively few are original. For the most part, nouns are formed by the use of honorific prefixes. There are perhaps just a dozen or so such prefixes, corresponding to honorific terms for body parts: སྐུ་ “body,” ཕྱག་ “hand,” དབུ་ “head,” སྤྱན་ “eyes,” ཞལ་ “mouth,” ཞབས་ “leg,” ལྗགས་ “tongue,” ཐུགས་ “mind,” བཀའ་ “speech,” as well as a few prefixes derived from verbs: གསོལ་ “to pray,” བཞེས་ “to take,” གཟིམ་ “to sleep,” etc.

Each prefix is associated with a very wide semantic field related to its original meaning. Thus the prefix སྐུ་ often appears in words denoting not only body parts but also physical activities, bodily representations, kinship ties, clothing, belongings, social ranks, certain illnesses, and so on. For example: སྐུ་ཁྲག་ “blood,” སྐུ་སྟོད་ “shirt,” སྐུ་ཆས་ “possessions,” སྐུ་བརྙན་ “statue,” སྐུ་མགྲོན་ “guest,” etc.

Verbs fall into two categories:

1. Verbs consisting of a noun and a verbalizer (these constitute the majority)

2. Simple verbs

In the first case, the honorific is obtained by putting the noun that precedes the verb in the honorific (according to the principle outlined above) and then replacing the verbalizer by its honorific (or humilific) homologue. Here are some verbs with common honorific verbalizers:

  • གནང་ honorific for བྱེད་ “to do” (verbalizer) and སྤྲད་ “to give”
  • བསྐྱོན་ honorific for བརྒྱབ་ “to do,” “to make” (verbalizer)
  • བཏང་གནང་ honorific for བཏང་ “to send” (verbalizer)
  • བཞེས་ honorific for ལེན་ “to take,” ཟ་ “to eat,” འཐུང་ “to drink”
  • ཞུས་ humilific for ཟ་ “to eat,” འཐུང་ “to drink,” ལེན་ “to take,” བཤད་ “to say”
  • ཕུལ་ humilific for སྤྲད་ “to give”
  • བཞེངས་ honorific for ལངས་ “to rise” (verbalizer)

 Following are some examples of verbs with these honorific verbalizers:

  • ལས་ཀ་བྱེད་ “To work” > ཕྱག་ལས་གནང་ (H)
  • ཇ་འཐུང་ “To drink tea” > གསོལ་ཇ་མཆོད་ (H) or གསོལ་ཇ་ཞུས་ (h)
  • མེ་བཏང་ “To set fire” > ཞུགས་མེ་བཏང་གནང་ (H)
  • དཔར་རྒྱབ་ “To photograph” > སྐུ་དཔར་བསྐྱོན་ (H)

In the case of certain simple verbs, the honorific entails a different lexical root.

  • འགྲོ་ “To go” > ཕེབས་ (H)
  • མཐོང་ “To see” > གཟིགས་ (H)

Note that there are only a few adjectives and adverbs that have a true honorific form. In such cases, the honorific has a different root from the ordinary term.

  • སྐྱིད་པོ་ “Happy,” “pleasant,” and ཞིམ་པོ་ “Delicious” > སྤྲོ་པོ་ (H)
  • མཉམ་དུ་ “Together” > ལྷན་རྒྱས་ (H)
  • མགྱོགས་པོ་ “Fast,” “quickly” > སྩོལ་པོ་ (H, rare)

In a few rare cases, the honorific form of the adjective is formed by using a suffix གནང་པོ་ pronounced གནང་གོ་:

  • འབོལ་པོ་ “Soft” > འབོལ་གནང་གོ་
  • མགོ་ཚོད་པོ་ “Capable” > དབུ་ཚོད་གནང་གོ་
  • དབེན་པོ་ “Quiet,” “calm” > དབེན་གནང་གོ་

Finally, it should be emphasized that respect is shown not only by using terminology but through a wide repertoire of appropriate gestures. Even nowadays, in many rural areas, people greet visitors by protruding their tongues, joining their hands and bowing slightly. The guest of honor always goes first and takes the highest seat, usually located in the innermost part of the room. He always receives the choicest food, served with deferential gestures in a quiet voice, and so on.

[1] This term was coined by Beyer; see The Classical Tibetan Language (Albany: State University of New York Press, 1992).

[2] The use of honoriﬁc registers may entail true linguistic virtuosity, to the extent that not only pronouns, but also adjectives, adverbs, verbs, and auxiliaries should be in honoriﬁc form, while the speaker should also diminish himself or herself by using the appropriate humiliﬁcs.
